data.title: Typo Cipher
data.solution:
"""
author: RajdeepBiswas.
Please note that the below solution is lengthy purely due to readability reasons.
In real competition time, there can be much simpler solutions.
"""

class TypoCipher():
    
    

    row_top = ''
    row_mid = ''
    row_bot = ''
    row_top_rot = ''
    row_mid_rot = ''
    row_bot_rot = ''
    keys_dict = {}
    food = []
    



    def __init__(self):
        
        
        self.row_top = 'qwertyuiop'
        self.row_mid = 'asdfghjkl'
        self.row_bot = 'zxcvbnm'

        self.row_top_rot = self.row_top
        self.row_mid_rot = self.row_mid
        self.row_bot_rot = self.row_bot
        
        self.food = ['Taco', 'Enchilada']


    
    def generate_shift_strings(self, key, direction):


        strings_source = [
            self.row_top,
            self.row_mid,
            self.row_bot
        ]


        strings_target = [
            self.row_top_rot,
            self.row_mid_rot,
            self.row_bot_rot
        ]


        if direction == 1:
                
            for i in range(len(strings_target)):
                
                k = key % len(strings_target[i])
                strings_target[i] = strings_target[i][k: ] + strings_target[i][: k]
                
        else:
                
            for i in range(len(strings_target)):
                
                k = -key % len(strings_target[i])
                strings_target[i] = strings_target[i][k: ] + strings_target[i][: k]


        for str_type in range(len(strings_source)):
                
            for letter in range(len(strings_source[str_type])):
                
                self.keys_dict[
                    strings_source[str_type][letter]
                ] = strings_target[str_type][letter]

            

    def decrypt_string(self, string, food, time):


        direction = self.food.index(food)
        key = int(time[:-2])


        self.generate_shift_strings(key, direction)


        result = ''

        
        for letter in string:
            
            if letter in self.keys_dict:
                result += self.keys_dict[letter]
                
            else:
                result += letter

        return result



if __name__ == '__main__':


    string = input()
    food = input()
    time = input()

    sol = TypoCipher()
    print(sol.decrypt_string(string, food, time))
data.statement:
Mutahar makes a lot of typos. You're tasked to decrypt what he was originally trying to type.

Good thing is that his typos are very predictable. They follow these patterns -

1. All his letters are leftshifted on the keyboard if he ate a {{Taco}} before typing.
2. All his letters are rightshifted on the keyboard if he ate an {{Enchilada}} before typing.
3. The hour of the day is also going to determine by how many <<key(s)>> he is going to shift by. For example if it is 5PM, it is going to shift by 5 keys.
4. His typos only affect lowercase alphabets.

Note that typos rotate around the keyboard for a specific row. For example, if he's ate a {{Taco}} and he types an {{a}} at {{1AM}}, the result is going to be {{l}}.

testCases.title: Test 3
testCases.testIn:
Jrmul yvpq wfp Lkze ayd
Taco
7AM

data.constraints:
0 < length([[string]]) < 5000.
[[food]] = {{Taco}} or {{Enchilada}}.
3 <= length([[time]]) <= 4.

string, food and time are of type string.
data.stubGenerator:
read string:string(5000)
read food:string(15)
read time:string(4)
write answer
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1>>: [[string]]
<<Line 2>>: [[food]]
<<Line 3>>: [[time]]

Muta uses a QWERTY keyboard. The keys look as follows from top to bottom row -

{{QWERTYUIOP}}
{{ASDFGHJKL}}
{{ZXCVBNM}}

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Mutahar makes a lot of typos. You're tasked to decrypt what he was originally trying to type.

Good thing is that his typos are very predictable. They follow these patterns -

1. All his letters are leftshifted on the keyboard if he ate a Taco before typing.
2. All his letters are rightshifted on the keyboard if he ate an Enchilada before typing.
3. The hour of the day is also going to determine by how many key(s) he is going to shift by. For example if it is 5PM, it is going to shift by 5 keys.
4. His typos only affect lowercase alphabets.

Note that typos rotate around the keyboard for a specific row. For example, if he's ate a Taco and he types an a at 1AM, the result is going to be l.
Input
Line 1: string
Line 2: food
Line 3: time

Muta uses a QWERTY keyboard. The keys look as follows from top to bottom row -

QWERTYUIOP
ASDFGHJKL
ZXCVBNM
Output
Line 1: result string
Constraints
0 < length(string) < 5000.
food = Taco or Enchilada.
3 <= length(time) <= 4.

string, food and time are of type string.
Example
Input
QeEtTu
Taco
11PM
Output
QwErTy
